_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Note:  This facility was previously part of the DuPont Sabine River Works Plant.  On April 30, 2004, the facility assets were purchased by INVISTA S.a r.l.



1.0  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



INVISTA Orange Site (INVISTA) management is committed to preventing process-related incidents that might affect plant personnel, off-site communities, the environment, or result in significant property or business loss. We firmly believe that we can operate our processes without inuring or endangering employees or the community. 



Our policy for process safety management is to comply with INVISTA Process Safety Management Standard, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (40 CFR Part 68). The INVISTA Orange site's Risk Management Program contains the management systems and controls for our diversified processes so that potential hazards are identified, understood, and controlled. It is the responsibility of each individual employee to know, understand, and comply with the site process safety management policy and systems. 



Management ensures that employees are involved in all aspects of the Risk Management reviews, auditing, and development of procedures and training programs.





1.1 THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The INVISTA Orange Site is located approximately 2 miles South of the city of Orange on FM 1006. The site is located on 72 acres and the facility is secured by a chain-link fence, video cameras, controlled entry, and a 24 hour security force. DuPont as the land owner is responsible for security and emergency response for the site.



The site consists of manufacturing processes to produce Nylon Intermediates [hexamethylenediamine (HMD), adipic acid (Adipure), and Adiponitrile (ADN)]. In the production of these products, the following r

egulated substances are used as raw materials, intermediates, or by-products:

- Ammonia (anhydrous)

- Ammonia (conc 20% or greater)

- Chlorine

- Hydrocyanic Acid (HCN)

- 1,3-Butadiene





1.2 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The regulated substances and corresponding processes at INVISTA are also regulated under the OSHA PSM standard. The PSM and RMP programs share common accidental release prevention requirements and corresponding program elements. In complying with the PSM standard, INVISTA has taken the necessary steps to comply with the applicable accidental release prevention requirements of the RMP regulation.



INVISTA's Accidental Release Prevention Program incorporates safety into process and equipment designs:

- A documented process technology system covers hazards of materials, equipment design basis, and process design basis.

- Extensive accident prevention and mitigation systems are strategically located.

- Applicable codes and standards are met or exceeded.

- Materials of construction are chosen to provide mechanical integrity.

- Quality Assurance ensures fabrication in accordance with design specifications and proper assembly.



INVISTA maintains the regulated processes with safety in mind:

- Maintenance personnel are qualified and trained.

- Contractors are trained and qualified.

- A work permit system controls hazards.

- All non-replacements-in-kind (non-RIK) changes are documented through site Management of Change (MOC) procedure.



INVISTA incorporates safety into regulated process operations:

- Operators are trained and job qualified.

- Technical resources are available and utilized as required.

- Operators follow approved procedures.



INVISTA audits the prevention program and its implementation:

- Routine safety inspections are conducted.

- Corporate, independent and governmental audits and reviews are conducted.

- Process Hazards Analyses are conducted.

- Safe

ty equipment are set up on a periodic inspection frequency to ensure ongoing mechanical integrity.

- Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted prior to starting up any new or modified equipment.

- Quality assurance of critical equipment ensures fabrication in accordance with design specifications.

- Incidents are investigated and actions taken to prevent recurrence.





1.3 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



In the last 5 years, the INVISTA Orange site has not experienced a release of a regulated substance that resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, or the need for evacuation or sheltering in place.  However, on October 10, 2012, the site had a release of a regulated substance that resulted in two onsite injuries.  The release was attributed to an upstream isolation valve that was not fully closed when a downstream flange was removed.  Contributing factors to the event include implementation of procedures for energy control and establishment of perimeters during line break activities.



1.4 Emergency Response Program



Plant personnel are trained and equipped to respond to any releases of the regulated chemicals. The INVISTA Orange site has a service level agreement with DuPont. Key program provisions include:

- Plant personnel receive emergency response training.

- Plant emergency responders, including the INVISTA Orange site and DuPont personnel, are trained.

- Emergency response plans are current.

- Plant participates in emergency drills.

- Critiques are held on drills and actual events.

- Plant is a member of the Orange County Local Emergency Planning Committee.



If a major release occurs, the following actions are taken:

- Emergency alarm is sounded.

- Community emergency responders are notified as appropriate.

- Emergency communicated to DuPont, which activates the Plant Emergency Operating Center.

- Plant Incident Commander and emergency squad respond.





1.5 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 



Through process hazard analyses,

the INVISTA Orange site has developed actions and implementation schedules for improving the safety of its regulated processes. The list of actions and implementation schedule are presented in PHA reports maintained in facility files.
